subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASE CALENDAR IS AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION OF THE WEBSITE: Highlights include Australian Retail Sales
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
10th January 2020

GEOPOLITICS

Rockets have reportedly landed in the vicinity Balad airbase, which is North of Baghdad, according to Sumaria. Iraqi police forces say the rockets hit near the Balad military base which houses US troops. (Newswires)

US government officials are now confident the Ukraine airliner - Boeing (BA) 737-800 - was shot down by an Iranian missile, citing satellite data. US President Trump said he has suspicions regarding the Boeing (BA) jet crash in Iran noting "somebody could have made a mistake", has a feeling something very terrible happened with the jet. Iranian aviation regulator chief says it is "impossible" that a missile hit the Ukrainian plane (BA), according to ISNA. (Newswires)

Senior Iranian Guards Commander said the missile attacks against the US began a operation which will continue across the region; aim is to get US troops expelled from the region. Iranian Commander Hajizadeh has reportedly said that 15-minutes after the strike at Ain-al-Asad a major electronic warfare operation was undertaken, with American drones out of control for moments, a major psychological blow., Iranian Front Page Editor. (Newswires/Twitter)

Iran President Rouhani said it will return to the JCPOA commitments if Europe does so in a phone call with UK PM Johnson. (Newswires)

Libya's Hafta has rejected ceasefire request from Turkey and Russia, according to AFP. (AFP)

Italy is testing the market's mood for a new 15-year and 30-year BTP, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said he might want to wait till after the election to complete Phase Two China trade deal, but also says will begin Phase Two straight away. (Newswires)

 

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Kashkari (Voter, Dove) said he is not concerned about low rates causing corporations to take on too much debt, but is more concerned with banks holding the debt, wants to ensure they have enough capital. Kashkari added that business investment is low due to tariff uncertainty, where an improvement in trade tensions could support gains in optimism; doesn't see a recession in the next few years (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Voter, Neutral) said the 1.5%-1.75% FFR range is "roughly appropriate" setting; sees between 2% to 2.25% growth in 2020, outlook has "firmed" in recent weeks, if anything; expects unemployment to fall further and inflation rising to the 2% goal. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) said he is content where rates are currently, and Fed should asses the lagged effects of the recent rate moves. Bullard added that there is reasonable chance of a soft landing in the US in 2020 due to the fast growth of 2018 and 2019's risks; businesses are remaining profitable despite trade uncertainty. If tensions in the Middle East pushes up oil prices the US will be more resilient in the face of any energy shock. Bullard favours a standing repo facility as a long-term solution; wants to keep the balance sheet as small as possible and feels a standing repo facility would help achieve that if banks feel they can source reserves from the Fed as needed (Newswires/WSJ)

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dovish) expects that there could be no rate changes in 2020 and said if something happened that caused the economy to slow, that would call for a monetary response; inflation is anchored, maybe too low, doesn't see inflation leading to monetary tightening. Evans added that the US economy is in a very good place; expects employment growth to decelerate over time; sees inflation reaching 1.9% this year (in-line with Fed median dot plot), with current rates supporting inflation (Newswires)

Fed’s Clarida (Voter) said there is some indication that global growth headwinds are beginning to abate; Fed would respond materially to any material assessment of the outlook. (Newswires)

Fed Discount Rate Minutes noted that all 12 regional banks voted to keep the rate steady; describe economic conditions as "positive" and were "optimistic about the prospect for economic growth". Several observe weakness in the manufacturing sector. Labour markets remain strong, with attracting new workers a challenge. On wage growth, the minutes note current and expected wage pressures. (Newswires)

BoE Governor Carney says that the bar for changing the inflation targeting regime is high. But it is nonetheless healthy to review it periodically, and that review is supported by the Bank’s active research agenda. All told, a reasonable judgement is that the combined conventional and unconventional policy space is in the neighbourhood of the 250 basis points cut to Bank Rate seen in pre-crisis easing cycles. (Newswires)

BoC Governor Poloz said it seems potential downside risks of the trade dispute have eased as the US and China approach a deal; remains to be seen if trade policy improvements feed through to economy recovery and investment. Poloz cited strikes and bad weather as contributing factors to the weak data; inflation has been very close to the 2% target and economy has been close to capacity for nearly two years. (Newswires)

 

US 

DATA RECAP

-        US Initial Jobless Claims w/e 214k vs. Exp. 220.0k (Prev. 222.0k, Rev. 223k)

 

MARKET RECAP

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.64% at 3274; NDX +0.87% at 8990, DJI +0.74% at 28957.* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) had a relief rally amid evidence emerging that its 737-800 jet, which fatally crashed in Iran, was due to it being hit by a missile rather than a technical fault with the jet. Kohl’s (KSS) tumbled lower after disappointing holiday season sales and lowering guidance, L Brands (LB) had a similar story although the stock reversed its premarket losses; however, the wider apparel sector (XRT, GPS, PVH, M) was a noted laggard. Lower energy prices saw the energy sector (XLE, XOP, XES) trail the rest of the pack. Apple (AAPL) made gains on AppleInsider reporting strong China iPhone sales in addition to a Pt rise at Jefferies. Goldman Sachs (GS) was supported by upgrades at both BofA and Berenberg; the higher yields also helped the wider financial sector (XLF, BKX) and Citi (C) was awarded the “Pick of the Decade” title from BofA too. AMD (AMD) surged after an upgrade at Mizuho upgraded the stock to Buy on an optimistic view of the server market. Tesla (TSLA) pared some of its recent rally as the share price flirts with USD 500; Baird also suggested investors hold a neutral stance and take profits. eBay (EBAY) opened on the back foot amid a downgrade at Jefferies, citing survey data that suggests the platform is losing consumer interest. Align Technology (ALGN) was an outperformer amid an upgrade to Outperform at Wolfe Research. Archer Daniels Midlands (ADM) and McCormick (MKC) suffered from downgrades at Monness Crespi and UBS, respectively. Ross Stores (ROST) benefitted from a PT rise at Cowen, citing inventory availability and improving macro backdrop. Mylan (MYL) underperformed amid a Neutral initiation at Piper Sandler and cautious comments at RBC.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 4 TICKS HIGHER AT 128-28+. The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Thursday. The session started off with a horizontal/downward bias, though a solid 30-year auction brought out the buyers. The auction itself stopped through the screens by a hefty 1.7bps, with analysts noting positive internals, where cover rose to a two-year high of 2.53x; dealer take-down was below recent averages, direct takedown was in line with recent averages, while the indirect bid was slightly above. Following the calming of geopolitical risk on Wednesday, which at the very least removes any immediate threat of military escalation between the US/Iran, and along with decent ISM services data and an ADP jobs report that surprised to the upside on Wednesday, the conditions appear to be in place to allow Treasury shorts to resume, desk noted. Some desks also suggest that rate unlocking in the corporate space has also added to the upward bias in yields.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 9th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 9th January 2020: Ukraine jet likely struck down by Iran

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude flat

* REAR VIEW: US says Iran shot down Ukraine jet, meanwhile rocket attacks in Iraq continue; Jobless claims mark another better-than-expected labour market data point; disappointing US retailer holiday sales; China confirms Washington trip for 13-15 Jan

* COMING UP: Data: US & Canadian labour report; US wholesale sales. Speakers: BoE’s Tenreyro; EU Foreign Ministers meeting to determine ways to solve the Iranian Nuclear Deal.

 

* IRAN: The latest reports from US officials, citing satellite data, suggest that the Ukraine aircraft that crashed in Iran was likely hit by an Iranian rocket, rather than a technical failure in the Boeing (BA) jet. US President Trump has said Iran hitting the commercial aircraft was likely a mistake, occurring amid Iran’s rocket strike in the Green Zone, Iraq. More generally, despite Trump opting to avoid escalating military tensions in the Middle East on Wednesday, it is clear the proxy wars between US and Iran are in full swing. Late Wednesday, there were more rocket attacks in Baghdad's Green Zone near the US embassy (no US casualties reported), highlighting that a serious risk of military escalation remains, although it was interesting that markets chose to look-through the attack, despite the rockets landing only 100m from the US embassy. Wednesday's attack in Baghdad was attributed to the Shiite militia Asaib Ahl al-Huq, which had threatened retaliation over the killing of the deputy head of the Iraqi Kataib Hezbollah militia, Stratfor said. Additionally, on Thursday, a senior IRGC commander said that Iran would take harsher revenge on the US soon. There was also another strike against a US-affiliated airbase North of Baghdad, Balad, in the latter part of the session, local police reported that the rockets hit near the base rather than directly on it, although the fresh strike saw some pickup in energy prices and some volatility in US equity futures.

* INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS: Weekly data showed initial jobless claims falling 9k to 214k, beneath the consensus 220k. Analysts note that the spike in early December, seeing claims rise to 252k, has now fully reversed, which suggests seasonal factors may have been in play over the holiday period, rather than a sharp deterioration in the labour market. It has also been noted that the deterioration in business surveys has not filtered through into layoffs. Attention now focusses on Friday's employment situation report.

* PREVIEW: US EMPLOYMENT SITUATION REPORT (FRIDAY): The Street looks for a sub-trend 164k payroll additions in December; the ADP data presents some upside to the consensus view, some argue. The unemployment rate seen unchanged, though some gauges suggest downside. The annual pace of wage growth is seen steady, though the monthly rate is seen picking-up. Business surveys are mixed: ISM data shows some cooling of labour market momentum, though its Markit counterpart has picked up – services employment rose at the fastest pace since July, manufacturing employment saw the second best reading since May. Job cuts data augurs well, with the monthly total having fallen to the lowest since July 2018. To download the report, please click here.

* FED: Fed’s Clarida (voter) speaking on the economy noted there is some indication that global growth headwinds are beginning to abate; reiterated Fed’s guidance that it would respond materially to any material assessment of the outlook.  Clarida stated we entered 2020 with the economy growing around trend rate, and downside risks have diminished but he sees inflation risks as skewed to the downside. On policy, rate cuts last year were well-timed, and supported the economy. Strong labour market is not putting any undue pressure on inflation; repeats economy in a good place, inflation still muted but expected to rise. On repo-operations, said Fed will adjust details of repo operations as appropriate, though ongoing purchases may be needed at least through April. Fed's Kashkari (voter, dove) said business investment is low due to tariff uncertainty, where an improvement in trade tensions could support gains in optimism; doesn't see a recession in the next few years. Kashkari added that the Fed is in a much better position to lift inflation now that rates are on pause; sees a pause in rates for the foreseeable future, dependent on the inflation outlook. The Minneapolis Fed President added that he is not concerned about low rates causing corporations to take on too much debt, but is more concerned with banks holding the debt, and wants to ensure they have enough capital. Fed's Kaplan (voter) said current rates are the roughly appropriate setting; sees between 2% to 2.25% growth in 2020, saying outlook has "firmed" in recent weeks, if anything; expects unemployment to fall further and inflation rising to the 2% goal. When mulling a potential rate change, Kaplan said the Fed will look at growth, inflation and financial stability. Kaplan is willing to tolerate inflation above 2%, but also cognizant of financial stability; open to longer-term averaging for the inflation target but does not want it as a "commitment". Kaplan wants to actively explore options to limit the growth in the balance sheet; doesn't want the balance sheet to fuel instability. Fed's Evans (non-voter, dovish) said the US economy is in a very good place, with rates in the right place to support it; expects employment growth to decelerate over time; sees inflation reaching 1.9% this year (in-line with Fed median dot plot), with current rates supporting inflation. Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dove) said he is content where rates are currently, and the Fed should asses the lagged effects of the recent rate moves. Bullard favours the standing repo facility as a long-term solution, which he believes could help keep the balance sheet from growing too large. Bullard said there is reasonable chance of a soft landing in the US in 2020 due to the fast growth of 2018 and 2019's risks; businesses are remaining profitable despite trade uncertainty. On recent geopolitics, Bullard said that if tensions in the Middle East push up oil prices, the US will be more resilient in the face of any energy shock.

* US-CHINA: China confirmed that Vice Premier Liu He will visit the US between 13-15th January to sign the Phase One trade deal. The nation's media had previously been reticent to confirm the visit officially. Other information was scant.

* WTI (G0) SETTLED USD 0.05 LOWER AT USD 59.56/BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLED USD 0.07 LOWER AT USD 65.37/BBL. Energy markets traded choppy on Thursday to settle little changed. The benchmarks spent most of the earlier session on the back foot until reports suggested the Ukrainian flight that crashed in Iran had potentially been shot down by an Iranian missile. Additionally, further reports of more missile attacks near US-affiliated bases in Iraq brought bidders to the market in the latter part of the session reversing some of the earlier losses.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.64% at 3274; NDX +0.87% at 8990, DJI +0.74% at 28957.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) had a relief rally amid evidence emerging that its 737-800 jet, which fatally crashed in Iran, was due to it being hit by a missile rather than a technical fault with the jet. Kohl’s (KSS) tumbled lower after disappointing holiday season sales and lowering guidance, L Brands (LB) had a similar story although the stock reversed its premarket losses; however, the wider apparel sector (XRT, GPS, PVH, M) was a noted laggard. Lower energy prices saw the energy sector (XLE, XOP, XES) trail the rest of the pack. Apple (AAPL) made gains on AppleInsider reporting strong China iPhone sales in addition to a Pt rise at Jefferies. Goldman Sachs (GS) was supported by upgrades at both BofA and Berenberg; the higher yields also helped the wider financial sector (XLF, BKX) and Citi (C) was awarded the “Pick of the Decade” title from BofA too. AMD (AMD) surged after an upgrade at Mizuho upgraded the stock to Buy on an optimistic view of the server market. Tesla (TSLA) pared some of its recent rally as the share price flirts with USD 500; Baird also suggested investors hold a neutral stance and take profits. eBay (EBAY) opened on the back foot amid a downgrade at Jefferies, citing survey data that suggests the platform is losing consumer interest. Align Technology (ALGN) was an outperformer amid an upgrade to Outperform at Wolfe Research. Archer Daniels Midlands (ADM) and McCormick (MKC) suffered from downgrades at Monness Crespi and UBS, respectively. Ross Stores (ROST) benefitted from a PT rise at Cowen, citing inventory availability and improving macro backdrop. Mylan (MYL) underperformed amid a Neutral initiation at Piper Sandler and cautious comments at RBC.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 4 TICKS HIGHER AT 128-28+. The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Thursday. The session started off with a horizontal/downward bias, though a solid 30-year auction brought out the buyers. The auction itself stopped through the screens by a hefty 1.7bps, with analysts noting positive internals, where cover rose to a two-year high of 2.53x; dealer take-down was below recent averages, direct takedown was in line with recent averages, while the indirect bid was slightly above. Following the calming of geopolitical risk on Wednesday, which at the very least removes any immediate threat of military escalation between the US/Iran, and along with decent ISM services data and an ADP jobs report that surprised to the upside on Wednesday, the conditions appear to be in place to allow Treasury shorts to resume, desk noted. Some desks also suggest that rate unlocking in the corporate space has also added to the upward bias in yields.

* BOC GOVERNOR POLOZ: When asked about recent weak data, Poloz cited strikes and bad weather as contributing factors. On inflation, he said it has been very close to the 2% target, which if on target, the bank can treat every shock symmetrically. Poloz said it seems potential downside risks of the trade dispute have eased as the US and China approach a deal; remains to be seen if trade policy improvements feed through to economy recovery and investment. Further on trade, he said the USMCA deal will remove a large source of uncertainty for many Canadian firms once ratified; BoC is looking for signs that the trade dispute is affecting sectors outside of those which heavily export, with recent data mixed. Poloz also said that perhaps the lesson is not to ignore what markets tell you, but also consider they are prone to exaggeration; the bank is watching the labour market to see if the recent moderation in strength persists. On the housing market, Poloz said that if the rebound strengthens, the BoC will be looking for signs of froth; demand seems to be outpacing the ability to build new homes.

* BOE: As BOE Governor Mark Carney heads for the door at Threadneedle Street, he presented an overview of the potential policy routes facing the UK under the current framework. The most widely-covered excerpt from his speech was where he noted that "at present, there is sufficient headroom to at least double the August 2016 package of GBP 60bln asset purchases, a number that will increase with further gilt issuance. That would deliver the equivalent of around a 100bps cut to the Bank Rate on top of the near 75 basis points of conventional policy space". All-in-all, the Governor concluded that the above suggests the combined policy space (when considering conventional and unconventional measures) would amount to equivalently around the 250bps of rate cuts that was seen in pre-crisis easing cycles. These comments were covered in an abbreviated form by major news vendors and were perhaps presented in a more suggestive manner than those made by Carney himself, who appeared to take a relatively even-handed approach when discussing interest rates. Nonetheless, markets took his overall speech as dovish with focus also placed on a comment highlighting "debate within the MPC over the merits of near-term stimulus to reinforce the anticipated recovery in UK growth and inflation". However, this shouldn't have come as too much of a surprise given the two dovish dissenters at the December meeting. With regards to the economic outlook, Carney noted the fragility of economic forecasts given the current uncertainties faced by the UK economy by stating "rebound forecast by the BoE for the UK economy this year is not assured". Overall, it could be argued that markets over-reacted to Carney's comments given the actual tone of the speech as a whole and the qualifications behind some of his statements; notwithstanding that, the Governor will be leaving the BOE in March, and thus, his comments should naturally carry less weight than they otherwise would. That said, the narrative surrounding policy at the Bank has titled in a more dovish direction following his remarks.

* BREXIT: Analysts note that Brexit risk has returned, after the UK recently legislated against extending the transition period beyond the end of this year. The first major battle between the EU and the UK is likely to be on the sequencing of trade talks. On Wednesday, new EU Commission President Von Der Leyen said time was tight to achieve a full trade agreement by the end of the year, and that any 2020 deal would likely be a narrow goods free trade agreement, with some scope for equivalence for services. Analysts speculate that the EU will push for trade talks to initially focus on goods and fishing rights, while the UK will want talks to take place on services equivalence. If negotiations fail, Politico reports that there might be a limited sector-by-sector approach from the EU, and although the EU would not prefer that strategy, since it might remove the EU's negotiating advantage, the UK would welcome it, setting the two sides on course for contentions negotiations; these risks are likely to materialise around March, when trade talks begin.

* UK RETAIL: BRC data revealed that, since 1995 when it began publishing its retail survey, 2019 was the first year to show a full-year decline in retail sales, at -0.1% Y/Y. Other data on Thursday from Barclayscard showed spending rising by an annualised 1.0% in December. 

* CHINA CPI (DEC): Consumer prices rose by 4.5% Y/Y in December, unchanged and beneath the consensus 4.7%. The pace of pork prices eased in the month. Some have noted that inflation will likely tick up again in January, due to seasonal effects around the Chinese New Year. However, pork prices are the key, with some arguing that if these stabilise further, the PBOC might have less concerns about lowering rates (NOTE: recall, China's Premier Li signalled lower rates for small enterprises, in his December speech). After the PBOC's recent RRR cut, which it says will release around CNY 800bln of liquidity to the banking system, desks now speculate that authorities may trim rates for the wider economy too, and focus is on the MLF and LPR rates, which could be cut in the weeks ahead. NOTE: Full-year CPI for 2019 came in at 2.9%, a touch beneath the government's 3.0% annual target.

* GERMANY INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION (NOV): +1.1% M/M, beating the expected +0.8%, and the Y/Y rate ticked up to -2.6% against a revised -4.6% in October. While the data looks good, relative to consensus, desks have noted that other survey data still looks soft, suggesting that momentum might not be sustained. Nevertheless, some desks said that the apparent rebound might continue into Q1 lifting GDP growth, but is due to base effects.

* GERMAN TRADE DATA (NOV): Exports declined 2.3% M/M, reversing October's 1.5% rise. Imports were down 0.5% in the month. The trade surplus narrowed to EUR 18.2bln from EUR 20.4bln.

* FX: * FX WRAP: The USD continued its upside, jobless claims did little to sway price action, DXY found resistance at 97.55 ahead of tomorrows NFP report. EUR was slightly firmer against the buck, with heavy option exiries in play around today’s NY cut, where 1.7bln rolled off at 1.1090-1.11, and 1.5bln at 1.1110-15. GBP saw initial downside after apparently dovish comments from BoE Governor Carney, who noted a reasonable judgement of combined conventional and unconventional policy space is around 250bps of easing. The CAD continued to lose ground, given the geopolitical risk premium pricing out of rude, which saw USDCAD briefly cross 1.31 to the upside, helped by broad dollar strength; CAD regained some ground against the buck after comments from Poloz who was optimistic on trade. CNH: Little reaction seen as pace of CPI growth slowed; traded sideways for the majority of US trade. USDJPY tested 109.50 to the upside as JPY continued to ease, with technicians eyeing December’s high 109.72 as the next key level to watch ahead of Friday’s jobs report, and the reduced geopolitical tensions. Gold continued to fade the recent geopolitically induced gains, finding support around USD 1,445 from overnight highs at 1,561 as Middle East tensions continue to ease. AUD was relatively unreactive to the overnight trade balance data, which saw a wider surplus than the previous and the expected. The Kiwi was the G10 laggard, continuing to fall after a weak ANZ commodity price index, which fell 2.8%. EMFX was weaker amid the broad dollar strength, with the exception of TRY, which is benefiting from falling oil prices. MXN was slightly weaker; data showed inflation falling, down to 2.83% Y/Y from 2.96% (Banxico’s target range is 3%). Weak industrial output added to BRL’s weakness, a 1.2% and 1.7% decline M/M and Y/Y respectively in November.   ZAR was softer amid poor manufacturing production data for November, which saw a 3.6% fall Y/Y and 1.5% fall M/M retracing some of the prior month’s gains.

content:
• Says a material change to him means a change in the growth outlook compared to the potential

content:
THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction anew 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday) and a 30-year re-opening (USD 16bln, Thursday). UBS says there will be a total of USD 26bln of cash flows (ex SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons; over the next four weeks, gross supply will total USD 191bln, the bank notes. 

30-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen thinks the 30-year sector appears slightly cheap in asset swap. The bank also notes that the current WI is trading below the last two auction stop-out rates, which could indicate relative richness, compared to those auctions. The December 30-year auction saw healthy demand, stopping through by a whopping 2.1bps, and ending the run of tails. SocGen also notes that 5s30s has steepened since the previous auction cycle, which might speaks to the relative cheapness of the sector. The bank has a positive bias going into the auction.

subject: Fed's Williams (voter, neutral) does not comment on monetary policy in his prepared remarks
PRIMER: Fed’s Williams (voter, neutral) speaking at a panel on ‘The future of Inflation Targeting’ at 16:30 GMT / 11:30 ET
content:
Recent commentary

  • On the economy, Williams noted the housing market is picking up from a year ago and consumer spending is strong, expects US economy to grow by about 2% over the next couple of years, says low and stable inflation isn't a concern, but wants to avoid falling inflation. He expects to see growth around 2.25%, unemployment around 3.5% and inflation remaining soft, haven’t seen inflationary pressures emerge, reiterates data dependence.
  • On policy, Williams noted monetary policy is accomodative and is supporting growth. Material change in economic outlook will cause him to change outlook. Williams says there are still significant risks to the downside, citing trade and geopolitical uncertainty. He believes monetary policy is in the right place.
  • On the repo-operations, says they have been very effective and money markets are moving smoothly.

Also of note

  • Fed median dots (2020): GDP +2%, Unemployment 3.5%, PCE +1.9%, Core PCE +1.9%, FFR 1.6% (no rate moves). NOTE: Atlanta Fed currently tracking GDP at 2.3% in Q4 19. 
  • Today’s Fed speeches (GMT): Voters - Kashkari at 19:15. Non-voters-: Barkin at 17:45, Evans at 18:20 and Bullard at 19:00

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar stands firm as most major and minor rivals falter
content:
DXY

Notwithstanding several wobbles and a few more broadsides from Iran threatening further retaliation, the Buck has held relatively firm and the index remains on course to continue its recovery towards the next bullish technical marker above 97.500 (having surpassed the 97.552 pre-NY break peak from December 27 at 97.562). US data has been supportive again on paper as initial claims fell more than forecast, albeit not in the survey week for Friday’s NFP, but the Greenback has largely benefited at the expense of others and another general improvement in risk appetite (on a combination of perceived less ME war threat and confirmation that Phase 1 of the US-China trade agreement will be signed off next Wednesday).

NZD/AUD

Not quite a nosedive, but the Kiwi has extended overnight losses (post-a weak ANZ commodity price index) throughout Thursday’s EU session to the point where it is now the biggest G10 laggard, with Nzd/Usd teetering over the 0.6600 handle and Aud/Nzd closer to 1.0400 than 1.0300, as the Aussie continues to hold above 0.6850 vs its US counterpart with some assistance from trade data revealing a wider than anticipated surplus.

JPY/GBP/CAD 

Also on the back foot, as the Yen succumbs to more safe-haven unwinding and in danger of losing the prop of buying interest around 109.50, while Sterling has had dovish sounding remarks from BoE Governor Carney to contend with alongside the aforementioned broadly bid Usd. However, Cable is off worst levels and trying to keep eyes on 1.3050, while Eur/Gbp has drifted down from 0.8530 ahead of the 4 pm fix, unlike Usd/Cad that is eyeing/testing 1.3100 offers following yet more poor Canadian data and with crude reversing even more of its geopolitical/supply related premium. Note, BoC’s Poloz is due to speak later and could acknowledge the recent spate of disappointing economic releases.

CHF/EUR

Narrowly mixed and therefore comparative ‘outperformers’, as the Franc and Euro both attempt to contain losses against the Dollar around 0.9725 and 1.1100 respectively, with the Eur/Chf cross straddling 1.0800 accordingly. To recap, hefty option expiries either side of the big figure stalled the steady Eur/Usd descent, while Swiss retail sales were somewhat mixed/inconclusive.

EM 

Bucking the recent trend, Usd/Try has held below 5.9000 for the most part as the Lira takes comfort from the latest (and pronounced) leg down in oil prices against the grain of most other Dollar/EM pairings that have rebounded from recent lows. However, the Yuans are back in the ascendency and probing fresh multi-month highs beyond 6.9200 at one stage for the Cnh on the news that a time and date has been set for the White House trade deal signing event noted above.

US EQUITY OPEN: Cash markets open at all time highs; SNAP +3%, AMD +2.4%, AAPL +1.5%, KSS -7.9%, ADM -2.2%, EBAY -1.1%
content:
Major US cash equity bourses have opened at fresh ATHs as the market abates fears of a near term conflict escalation between the US and Iran, despite potential for conflict via proxies. The narrative appears to be pivoting back towards the Phase One US-China deal which is expected to be signed in Washington next week, although there is skepticism on the agricultural purchases that China will actually make given it has recently said it would not raise the grain quota limit, and more recently its fresh purchase of soy beans from Brazil instead of the US.

Ahead of the NFP report on Friday, the data front has been thin in the US today aside from the jobless claims, which came in less than expected, which marks another positive labour market data release this week (after the strong ADP report) which has lead some analysts to warm to the view that the NFP figure on Friday could surprise to the upside (exp. 164k jobs added). Although the labour market looks to be resilient, its relevance to Fed policy is becoming more minute, where officials have stressed any consideration of a rate hike would only be considered once inflation moves higher in a sustained manner; conversely if the NFP report was to miss strongly to the downside, officials are much more attentive to the trend rather than single data points. Note that Fed's Williams (voter) is due to speak at 11:30 EST/ 16:30 GMT and Fed's Evans (non-voter) and Bullard (non-voter) are to speak later in the session.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt dips again, but Dollar remains underpinned
content: Another rebound in bonds has been thwarted by bears or sellers into upticks amidst more mixed NA data, as US claims decline more than expected in contrast to Canadian building permits that were even weaker than housing starts vs consensus. Bunds have backed off from a new 171.51 apex (-27 ticks vs -62 ticks at one stage), Gilts are back down from 131.66 (+10 ticks) and 10 year USTs just off 128-20+ vs 128-28+ at the other extreme. However, the Buck remains buoyant across the board and obviously against the Loonie as Usd/Cad works its way up and through 1.3050-60 offers to keep the DXY afloat between 97.245-501 parameters.

subject: Fed’s Clarida (voter) says there is some indication that global growth headwinds are beginning to abate; Fed would respond materially to any material assessment of the outlook
content:
• Says rate cuts last year were well-timed, and supported the economy
  • Strong labour market is not putting any undue pressure on inflation; repeats economy in a good place, inflation still muted but expected to rise
  • Says Fed will adjust details of repo operations as appropriate, though ongoing purchases may be needed at least through April
  • Clarida says we enter 2020 with the economy growing around trend rate, and downside risks have diminished
  • He sees inflation risks as skewed to the downside
analysis_details:
• While Clarida's comments are generally in line with what we would expect, his comments on repo operations are interesting, given the recent Fed meeting minutes revealed officials expect to transition away from active repo operations in mid-January; Clarida may have factored in some of the oversubscribed repo operations since the Fed's previous policy meeting.
  • (NOTE: April coincides with the year-end for tax payments)
  • High profile market commentator El Erian says one of his main takeaways from the remarks are that while the US economy remains in a good place, and international tensions have eased, the Fed appears to have Despite this, no intention to take back the 2019 "i, and the murance cuts" Main policy focus will be on repo-related balance sh.eet management

subject: PRIMER: Fed’s Clarida (voter, neutral) speaking on US economic outlook and monetary policy at 13:00 GMT/ 08:00 ET
content:
Recent commentary:

  • On policy, he does not see Fed taking forward guidance out of its toolkit and it will use its full arsenal of tools in the event of an economic downturn. Clarida highlighted that monetary policy did support the economy through the tough stretch last summer.
  • On the economy, notes the US consumer is in great shape and sees no signs of the consumer pulling back noting the US economy is in a good place and Fed’s baseline outlook for economy is more of the same for 2020.

Also of note

  • Fed median dots (2020): GDP +2%, Unemployment 3.5%, PCE +1.9%, Core PCE +1.9%, FFR 1.6% (no rate moves). NOTE: Atlanta Fed currently tracking GDP at 2.3% in Q4 19.
  • Today’s Fed speeches (GMT): Voters - Kashkari at 14:30 and Williams at 16:30. Non-voters-: Barkin at 17:45, Evans at 18:20 and Bullard at 19:00

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer, as markets return to risk-on following the Middle-East de-escalation
  • Senior Iranian Revolutionary Guard Commander states that Iran will take 'harsher revenge soon' following on from the missile attacks on US targets in Iraq., Tasnim
  • China and the US will sign the Phase One deal, which will occur on January 15th at 16:30GMT., Chinese Press
  • USD is outperforming G10 counterparts today, particularly GBP post-Carney
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Jobless Claims, Fed’s Clarida, Williams, Evans & Bullard, ECB’s Lane, supply from the US

GEOPOLITICS

US reportedly considered striking Iran after its attack on Iraqi airbases, but the decision was held off until more information was gathered regarding intent and casualties, according to CNN. (CNN)

US VP Pence said the US is receiving intelligence that Iran is telling militias not to move against US targets, CBS Interview. (CBS) US Chief of Staff stated that the US expects Shiite militias in Iraq to launch terrorist attacks against coalition forces. (Newswires) Iraqi Shiite militia spokesman said, "the response of the resistance factions will be very harsh, and the coming days will be full of surprises.", according to NBC News Analyst Kohnlan. (Twitter) - ELINT News noted that the Iranian-backed Iraqi Shia militias have so far not responded to the killing of 25 of their men in western Iraq and the assassination of al-Muhandis, who was the leader of Iraqi Hezbollah and deputy commander of the Popular Mobilisation Units. (Twitter) US Defence Secretary Esper said US military remains "poised and ready" - nothing major was damaged in yesterday's Iranian attacks on Iraqi bases. Defence Secretary Esper also tweeted "We can report 100% accountability of US personnel in Iraq", and added that US remains vigilant and calls on Iran to take this chance to de-escalate tensions. (Twitter)

Senior Iranian Revolutionary Guard Commander states that Iran will take 'harsher revenge soon' following on from the missile attacks on US targets in Iraq., Tasnim. (Newswires)

Iran's Ambassador to the UN states that the offer of co-operation from US President Trump is 'unbelievable' while Tehran remains under US sanctions., IRNA. (Newswires)

UN delegate to Iran said our countries are able to solve their problems through dialogue, including differences in the Gulf, and added that Tehran does not consider the Nuclear Deal to be dead following recent steps, reported via Al-Jazeera. (Twitter)

US justifies IRGC Commander Soleimani's killing as self-defence, US said it is prepared to take additional action in the Middle East to protect US personnel, US stands ready to engage in negotiations with Iran to prevent escalations, via a letter to UN. (Newswires) Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif reiterated that the people in the region wants the US out. (Twitter)

UN investigation reportedly found that Yemen Houthi's did not launch the attacks on the oil facilities in Saudi Arabia last September, according to a confidential report. The report found that “Some of those weapons have technical characteristics similar to arms manufactured in Iran” (Newswires)

NATO Secretary General, in response to US President Trump’s call for more involvement, said NATO could contribute more to the regional stability, according to The Times citing a NATO spokesman. (Times)

The initial Iranian investigation, into the Boeing (BA) crash, report noted that the plane had a technical problem prior to the crash. (Newswires) US intelligence looking into Boeing (BA) 737 crash in Tehran, according to CNN. (CNN) Note: There were also uncited reports that Iran may seek help from the US regarding the Boeing investigation after Tehran refused to hand over the plane’s black box. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac bourses kicked off the session with firm gains across the board after a positive handover from Wall Street - which saw the Nasdaq Comp notching intraday and closing records, whilst the S&P hit intraday all-time highs. Global sentiment was bolstered by what seems to be a simmering down in US-Iran tensions, with US President Trump also stating that the US is ready to embrace peace after saying that Iran appears to be standing down. US equity futures and cash experienced some losses heading into the Wall Street close amid reports of two rockets hitting Baghdad’s Green Zone near the US Embassy, although negative sentiment failed to materialise as no casualties were registered. ASX 200 (+0.8%) gleaned support from its largest weighted financials sector, but gains remained hindered as oil and precious metal names are pressured by recent price action in the respective complexes. Nikkei 225 (+2.3%) outperformed peers in the region as the index welcomed favourable JPY dynamics and with only a small fraction of its constituents in negative territory. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.9%) echoed the performance in regional peers after the Mainland initially side-lined below-forecast Chinese inflation figures for a bulk of the session, with the US-China Phase One deal signing drawing closer. 

Chinese CPI YY (Dec) 4.5% vs. Exp. 4.7% (Prev. 4.5%) (Newswires) Chinese PPI YY (Dec) -0.5% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. -1.4%)

PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9467 vs. Exp. 6.9464 (Prev. 9.9450) (Newswires) PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position

China and the US will sign phase one trade deal. This deal can be seen as a new start to explore each other's boundary of behavior and tolerance, according to Chinese Global Times Editor Hu Xijin. (Twitter) Deal is to be signed at 16:30GMT on January 15th, WSJ.

China's Foreign Ministry states that the US Congress report on their human rights is neither objective or credible. (Newswires)

Huawei is reportedly in talks with international banks to raise USD 2bln via loans and bond sales outside China, according to sources cited by The Information. (The Information)

China Finance Ministry reportedly to front load in excess of CNY 500bln quota for local government general purpose bond issuance, sources state, which added that it should be used up before March. (Newswires)

World Bank cut 2019 global growth forecast to 2.4% (Prev. 2.6%) and cut 2020 forecast to 2.5% (Prev. 2.7%) due to slower-than-expected recovery in trade and in investments 2019 EM growth forecasts cut to 3.5% (Prev. 4.0%) and 2020 forecast cut to 4.1% (Prev. 4.6%). (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK BRC Retail Sales Monitor (Dec) YY +1.7% (Prev. -4.9%) - distorted by timings of Black Friday sales. (Newswires)

German Industrial Output MM* (Nov) 1.1% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. -1.7%, Rev. -1.0%)

-        Trade Balance, EUR, SA* (Nov) 18.3B vs. Exp. 20.0B (Prev. 20.6B, Rev. 20.4B)

-        Imports MM SA* (Nov) -0.5% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Rev. 0.5%)

-        Exports MM SA* (Nov) -2.3% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Prev. 1.2%, Rev. 1.5%)

BoE Governor Carney: Rebound forecast by the BoE for the UK economy this year is not assured, Is debate within the MPC over the merits of near-term stimulus to reinforce the anticipated recovery in UK growth and inflation. All told, a reasonable judgement is that the combined conventional and unconventional policy space is in the neighbourhood of the 250 basis points cut to Bank Rate seen in pre-crisis easing cycles. Is sufficient headroom to release, at least, double the August 2016 GBP 60bln package of asset purchases; a number that is to increase with additional gilt issuance. (BoE/Newswires)

EQUITIES

European bourses are firmer this morning, in the next turn of what is proving to be a roller-coaster week for markets. This strength comes as comments from US President Trump yesterday intimated a de-escalation in tensions, more information available in the Commodity section below. This morning’s notable outperformer is the Dax, with the cash bourse having printed a high above the 13500 mark; marking a significant retracement/turnaround from the weeks low below the 12950 level, an over 500 point range already for the index. Sector wise, energy is this morning’s notable underperformer, on the aforementioned de-escalation in tensions in-line with the broader crude complex. Energy aside, the remaining bourses are in positive territory for the session. At the bottom of the Stoxx 600 this morning are Marks & Spencer (-9.4%), after providing a Q3 and Christmas Period trading update; in which, they did note that gross margins are expected at the lower-end of guidance, but this should be offset. In contrast, after also providing a holiday update, Tesco (+2.2%) are firmly in the green, the Co. highlighted that over the Christmas period they outperformed the market. UK supermarkets aside, flight names such as Air France (+4.3%) are benefitting on the reduction in oil-prices and calming of tensions; with Air France specifically having provided a strong December update this morning.

EU antitrust regulators have now recommenced their investigation into the Boeing (BA) and Embraer deal, following on from Boeing presenting requested data, decision is due by the 30th of April. (Newswires)

FX

USD - The great Greenback revival continues, albeit gradually, with the DXY nudging through 97.500 having picked off the next upside chart objectives at 97.344 and 97.350 to target December 27’s 97.552 high set before the broad Dollar was beset by portfolio selling for year end. The Buck is still forging gains or clawing back losses vs major rivals, and in particular those currencies deemed to be safer havens, with only a minor blip caused by several incendiary Iranian remarks earlier today, as investors take comfort from the fact that Tehran’s strike back did not irk US President Trump to the extent of further action beyond more sanctions.

GBP - Unexpectedly dovish commentary from BoE Governor Carney has pushed the Pound down to the bottom of the G10 rankings, as he raises some doubt about the anticipated 2020 economic recovery and reveals that the MPC is mulling whether it needs to help via additional stimulus. Moreover, he believes there is room to restart QE within a wider easing package equating to 250 bp and the APF more than twice the size of August 2016’s Gbp60 bn. Cable had already given up 1.3100+ status around the 9 am fix as Eur/Gbp squeezed up towards 0.8500, but Sterling declines subsequently extended to sub-1.3020 and circa 0.8530 respectively.

NZD/JPY/AUD - The Kiwi and Yen are also underperforming, as Nzd/Usd retests support/bids ahead of 0.6600 and Usd/Jpy probes offers/supply into 109.50. However, the former appears weak partly, if not mainly due to relative Aussie resilience near 1.0350 and 0.6850 vs its US peer in wake of a much wider than forecast trade surplus, while the latter may yet be drawn back down towards a very large option expiry at 109.25 (2.4 bn).

EUR/CHF/CAD/NOK/SEK - All softer against the Greenback or Euro in the case of the Scandi Crowns, but to varying degrees with the single currency and Franc holding up a bit better than others even though Eur/Usd has pulled back further from recent highs and into a heavy option expiry interest zone spanning the 1.1100 level (1.7 bn from 1.1090 to the round number and 1.5 bn between 1.1110-15). Meanwhile, Usd/Chf is trapped in a tight 0.9732-47 range following stagnant Swiss retail sales data (y/y) and Usd/Cad awaits Canadian housing starts and building permits before a late speech from BoC chief Poloz within 1.3026-56 confines, while Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek are both firmer circa 9.8700 and 10.5200, tracking overall risk sentiment, oil prices and for the Norwegian Krona also taking on board rather tepid monthly mainland GDP.

EM - Most regional currencies are basking or at least benefiting from the ongoing scale down of geopolitical angst, and Turkey’s Lira is delighted with the related retracement in crude costs that should aid efforts to bring inflation back to target ahead of schedule and allow the CBRT to normalise rates further. Usd/Try currently hovering close to 5.8750.

Australian Trade Balance G&S (A$) (Nov) 5.800B vs. Exp. 4.1500B (Prev. 4.502B, Rev. 4.075B) (Newswires)

Major FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1050 (1BLN), 1.1070 (400M), 1.1090-1.1100 (1.7BLN), 1.1110-15 (1.5BLN), 1.1125 (650M), 1.1140-50 (1.5BLN), 1.1200 (1.5BLN)

-        AUD/USD: 0.6840 (1.9BLN), 0.6880 (320M), 0.6895-0.6900 (1.2BLN)

-        USD/JPY: 108.45 (1.2BLN), 109.15 (575M), 109.25 (2.4BLN)

FIXED INCOME

Some range extension in EU debt during the am session, but no lasting turnaround or major game changer even though BoE Governor Carney sounded more inclined towards ensuring that growth picks up with fresh policy action given no guarantee that projections will be matched this year. His dovish-leaning comments have helped Short Sterling futures reverse early Liffe declines, but Gilts are back below parity vs +7 ticks at best, albeit doing better than Bunds that only mustered a new 171.46 Eurex intraday high before waning again. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are sitting tight after some hefty overnight block selling and awaiting this week’s final slug of issuance and the last anecdotal employment pointers ahead of Friday’s official monthly jobs report. Note also, several Fed orators on the docket later.

COMMODITIES

Today’s price action sees the crude complex in negative territory, as last nights remarks via US President Trump point to a de-escalation in the Middle East noting that he would prefer not to take a military response; albeit, POTUS did state the US is to implement further sanctions on Iran. However, subsequent remarks from a Iranian Commander state they will take ‘harsher revenge soon’ for the killing of Soleimani, following the missile strikes on US-Iraqi targets; recall, that Iran states these strikes were the least severe of the 13 options that they had considered. As such, this indicates that perhaps tensions have not entirely fizzled out, as the current market environment points towards. ING highlight that, recent price action, means speculators are now holding their largest net-long in Brent since October 2018; which they posit provides room for significant sell-off/liquidation of positions, particularly in the event that next week’s US-China signing disappoints. In-fitting with the de-escalation price action, spot gold has dropped below the USD 1550/oz mark, well off of yesterday’s USD 1600/oz+ highs. In other metals news, Brazilian state prosecutors intend to criminally charge Vale shortly regarding the Brumadinho dam collapse which resulted in the death of over 250 people.

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Risk-on returns as Middle-East frictions recede - 9th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European bourses are firmer this morning, in the next turn of what is proving to be a roller-coaster week for markets. This strength comes as comments from US President Trump yesterday intimated a de-escalation in tensions, more information available in the Commodity section below. This morning’s notable outperformer is the Dax, with the cash bourse having printed a high above the 13500 mark; marking a significant retracement/turnaround from the weeks low below the 12950 level, an over 500-point range already for the index. Sector wise, energy is this morning’s notable underperformer, on the aforementioned de-escalation in tensions in-line with the broader crude complex. Energy aside, the remaining bourses are in positive territory for the session. At the bottom of the Stoxx 600 this morning are Marks & Spencer (-9.4%), after providing a Q3 and Christmas Period trading update; in which, they did note that gross margins are expected at the lower-end of guidance, but this should be offset. In contrast, after also providing a holiday update, Tesco (+2.2%) are firmly in the green, the Co. highlighted that over the Christmas period they outperformed the market. UK supermarkets aside, flight names such as Air France (+4.3%) are benefitting on the reduction in oil-prices and calming of tensions; with Air France specifically having provided a strong December update this morning.

FX

USD - The great Greenback revival continues, albeit gradually, with the DXY nudging through 97.500 having picked off the next upside chart objectives at 97.344 and 97.350 to target December 27’s 97.552 high set before the broad Dollar was beset by portfolio selling for year end. The Buck is still forging gains or clawing back losses vs major rivals, and in particular those currencies deemed to be safer havens, with only a minor blip caused by several incendiary Iranian remarks earlier today, as investors take comfort from the fact that Tehran’s strike back did not irk US President Trump to the extent of further action beyond more sanctions.

GBP - Unexpectedly dovish commentary from BoE Governor Carney has pushed the Pound down to the bottom of the G10 rankings, as he raises some doubt about the anticipated 2020 economic recovery and reveals that the MPC is mulling whether it needs to help via additional stimulus. Moreover, he believes there is room to restart QE within a wider easing package equating to 250 bp and the APF more than twice the size of August 2016’s Gbp60 bn. Cable had already given up 1.3100+ status around the 9 am fix as Eur/Gbp squeezed up towards 0.8500, but Sterling declines subsequently extended to sub-1.3020 and circa 0.8530 respectively.

NZD/JPY/AUD - The Kiwi and Yen are also underperforming, as Nzd/Usd retests support/bids ahead of 0.6600 and Usd/Jpy probes offers/supply into 109.50. However, the former appears weak partly, if not mainly due to relative Aussie resilience near 1.0350 and 0.6850 vs its US peer in wake of a much wider than forecast trade surplus, while the latter may yet be drawn back down towards a very large option expiry at 109.25 (2.4 bn).

EUR/CHF/CAD/NOK/SEK - All softer against the Greenback or Euro in the case of the Scandi Crowns, but to varying degrees with the single currency and Franc holding up a bit better than others even though Eur/Usd has pulled back further from recent highs and into a heavy option expiry interest zone spanning the 1.1100 level (1.7 bn from 1.1090 to the round number and 1.5 bn between 1.1110-15). Meanwhile, Usd/Chf is trapped in a tight 0.9732-47 range following stagnant Swiss retail sales data (y/y) and Usd/Cad awaits Canadian housing starts and building permits before a late speech from BoC chief Poloz within 1.3026-56 confines, while Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek are both firmer circa 9.8700 and 10.5200, tracking overall risk sentiment, oil prices and for the Norwegian Krona also taking on board rather tepid monthly mainland GDP.

EM - Most regional currencies are basking or at least benefiting from the ongoing scale down of geopolitical angst, and Turkey’s Lira is delighted with the related retracement in crude costs that should aid efforts to bring inflation back to target ahead of schedule and allow the CBRT to normalise rates further. Usd/Try currently hovering close to 5.8750.

FIXED INCOME

Some range extension in EU debt during the am session, but no lasting turnaround or major game changer even though BoE Governor Carney sounded more inclined towards ensuring that growth picks up with fresh policy action given no guarantee that projections will be matched this year. His dovish-leaning comments have helped Short Sterling futures reverse early Liffe declines, but Gilts are back below parity vs +7 ticks at best, albeit doing better than Bunds that only mustered a new 171.46 Eurex intraday high before waning again. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are sitting tight after some hefty overnight block selling and awaiting this week’s final slug of issuance and the last anecdotal employment pointers ahead of Friday’s official monthly jobs report. Note also, several Fed orators on the docket later.

COMMODITIES

Today’s price action sees the crude complex in negative territory, as last nights remarks via US President Trump point to a de-escalation in the Middle East noting that he would prefer not to take a military response; albeit, POTUS did state the US is to implement further sanctions on Iran. However, subsequent remarks from a Iranian Commander state they will take ‘harsher revenge soon’ for the killing of Soleimani, following the missile strikes on US-Iraqi targets; recall, that Iran states these strikes were the least severe of the 13 options that they had considered. As such, this indicates that perhaps tensions have not entirely fizzled out, as the current market environment points towards. ING highlight that, recent price action, means speculators are now holding their largest net-long in Brent since October 2018; which they posit provides room for significant sell-off/liquidation of positions, particularly in the event that next week’s US-China signing disappoints. In-fitting with the de-escalation price action, spot gold has dropped below the USD 1550/oz mark, well off of yesterday’s USD 1600/oz+ highs. In other metals news, Brazilian state prosecutors intend to criminally charge Vale shortly regarding the Brumadinho dam collapse which resulted in the death of over 250 people.

subject: Nomura quants say uptrend in the S&P 500 looking stretched
content:
• Nomura quants note that market conditions swung yesterday, from distinclty risk-off in APAC trade, to risk-on by the end of US trade. Now, the bank says spec traders are piling back into US and equity longs after the US de-scalation gave way to a relief rally. The bank also notes that trend-chasing CTA's were "flummoxed"; CTAs brought their net buying of gold futures to a halt yesterday, although the sustained uptrend in gold futures prices meant that they did not go so far as to start scaling back the net long position they have accumulated in the aggregate.
  • With that said, Nomura says that gold futures prices could conceivably drop back below $1,500 (depending on what other investors do), in which case CTAs would become more likely to start downsizing their aggregate net long position.
  • The bank estimates that CTAs cut aggregate net longs in WTI crude by more than half, led mostly by loss-cutting executed in response to the rapid fallback in oil prices. Nomura estimates that the peak in the systematic sell-off came quickly as a result of CTAs’ having had only a small aggregate net long position to begin with.
  • Meanwhile, the bank says CTAs’ net long position in US equity futures lurches sharply upward. S&P 500 futures prices briefly dipped below 3,200 yesterday, and with then staged a steep rebound. "Once futures prices had climbed back above the trigger line at around 3,200, CTAs similarly did an about-face and flocked back to net buying in intraday trading," the bank says, "the result (according to our estimates) is that CTAs' cumulative net long position in S&P 500 futures lurched sharply upward." Nomura suggests that thiswas not isolated to the S&P 500 futures market; the same thing seems to have happened in NASDAQ 100 futures and DJIA futures.
  • Those three indices have now risen back above Nomura's estimates of the average entry points for long positions accumulated by CTAs since the beginning of December (3,235 for the S&P 500, 8,775 for the NASDAQ 100, and 28,600 for the DJIA). "CTAs, sitting on unrealized gains, therefore remained inclined to continue chasing these markets up," the bank says. However, the same is not true for the R2K futures, where CTAs continued to defensively close out long positions at an easy pace. (Nomura estimates that CTAs’ purchases of Russell 2000 futures since the beginning of December break even at around 1,660 on average.)
  • "Although systematic rather than discretionary, sustained buying flow by trend-chasers nevertheless does the job of supporting market supply-demand," Nomura writes, "we note in particular that when algorithmic traders are chasing the market up in the manner they now are, the stock market tends to take on at least a surface appearance of being resistant to risk-off sentiment," adding that "this appearance, in turn, tends to stoke optimism among fundamentals-oriented investors."
  • But, Nomura thinks it is also wise to pay attention to what looks like overcrowding in trend-chasing investors' strategy of accumulating long positions in US equities.
  • "In theory, trend-following algos can continue to increase their exposure (through pyramiding or leveraging up) for as long as the market uptrend continues, but in practice, however, steep stock market gains powered by supply-demand tend to become divorced from fundamentals, and position herding among trend-following investors leaves the market sensitive to even minute shocks, raising the risk of the accumulated positions being liquidated in a rapidly unfolding chain reaction."
  • Nomura believes the uptrend in the S&P 500 looking stretched, and CTAs’ accumulated net long position is starting to look shaky. So why has the market continued its seemingly untethered rise? "We would point to the tailwind provided on the liquidity front by factors including the Fed’s accommodative monetary policy. We also suspect that more than a few investors with an optimistic longer-term scenario in mind have remained inclined to keep up their buying of US stocks." But, the bank still thinks that anyone contemplating staking out fresh long positions from here may want to consider waiting until trend-following investors have let some pressure out of the system by paring their positions, as this would lessen the risk of getting hit by an unexpected drawdown."

subject: BoE Governor Carney says that the bar for changing the inflation targeting regime is high. But it is nonetheless healthy to review it periodically, and that review is supported by the Bank’s active research agenda
content:
• Rebound forecast by the BoE for the UK economy this year is not assured
  • Is debate within the MPC over the merits of near-term stimulus to reinforce the anticipated recovery in UK growth and inflation
  • Is sufficient headroom to release, at least, double the August 2016 GBP 60bln package of asset purchases; a number that is to increase with additional gilt issuance
  • All told, a reasonable judgement is that the combined conventional and unconventional policy space is in the neighbourhood of the 250 basis points cut to Bank Rate seen in pre-crisis easing cycles.
  • Link to Release
reaction_details: • These comments have caused a dovish reaction in UK assets, with Sterling coming under pressure and gilts moving back towards the unchanged level for the session. Note, some of this may be exacerbated by the abbreviation of remarks by Carney; explained in the Analysis section below
analysis_details:
• Note, Carney's term at the BoE will expire on the 16th March 2020.
  • Note, on social media a number of outlets are portraying an abbreviated version of the final comments from Governor Carney in this headline; with the full headline being "All told, a reasonable judgement is that the combined conventional and unconventional policy space is in the neighbourhood of the 250 basis points cut to Bank Rate seen in pre-crisis easing cycles". - note, the abbreviated version comes across more dovishly than the full comment; furthermore, the BoE have always pushed back on the prospect of negative rates.
  • For reference, the abbreviated comment is 'BoE has the equivalent of 250bps of policy space'

subject: Gilts gap down, and Short Sterling strip soft despite IRGC barbs
content: Breaking headlines from Iran have disrupted some of the calm, but UK bonds and STIR contracts are still observing the general sense of relief stoked by US President Trump in wake of Tehran’s retaliatory action that he deemed to be akin to the country backing off rather than inciting further conflict. Hence, the 10 year debt future remains deep in negative territory and skirting 131.00 compared to yesterday’s 131.56 close and the 3 month strip is 1.5-3 ticks adrift ahead of a speech by BoE Governor Carney and Gbp1 bn 2028 linker sale.

subject: Senior Iranian Revolutionary Guard Commander states that Iran will take 'harsher revenge soon' following on from the missile attacks on US targets in Iraq., Tasnim
reaction_details: • European and US equity futures did experience some very mild, and short-lived, decline. While the DXY and European debt futures saw some upside in a slightly delayed response
analysis_details:
• Follows on from comments from US President Trump last night, which were perceived as a de-escalation in the conflict as Trump only placed sanctions on Iran and indicated that he would prefer not to take a military response
  • As such, these comments out of Iran this morning indicate that the situation is yet to be fully resolved, and that we may see further military measures out of Iran; recall, that the strikes in Iraq were regarded by Iran as being the weakest out of the 13 possible options that they had identified in response to the assassination of Soleimani
  • Note, the Commander in question is Senior Commander Abdollah Araghi., Al Jazerra; adding that Iran remains in a period of religious mourning with ceremonies taking place 3, 7, and 40 days after death. Link to Article

subject: Bunds: bears take aim at January 3 base after breaching midweek low
content: The 10 year German benchmark has extended declines after another muted/tame bounce from opening levels and the path seems clear for sellers to probe deeper towards last week’s troughs as markets continue to reassess the US-Iran situation amidst signs of constraint on both sides. The core debt future recently took a run through yesterday’s Eurex session trough (172.26), but stopped just short of last Friday’s base (171.10) and is now attempting to consolidate around 171.30 within a 171.16-41 range vs Wednesday’s 171.78 close, with little net reaction to German ip, trade or current account data. Ahead, more hefty supply to absorb and a couple of ECB speakers after more pre-NFP US jobs proxies and Fed rhetoric.

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

9th January 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac bourses kicked off the session with firm gains across the board after a positive handover from Wall Street - which saw the Nasdaq Comp notching intraday and closing records, whilst the S&P hit intraday all-time highs. Global sentiment was bolstered by what seems to be a simmering down in US-Iran tensions, with US President Trump also stating that the US is ready to embrace peace after saying that Iran appears to be standing down. US equity futures and cash experienced some losses heading into the Wall Street close amid reports of two rockets hitting Baghdad’s Green Zone near the US Embassy, although negative sentiment failed to materialise as no casualties were registered. ASX 200 (+0.7%) gleaned support from its largest weighted financials sector, but gains remained hindered as oil and precious metal names are pressured by recent price action in the respective complexes. Nikkei 225 (+2.2%) outperformed peers in the region as the index welcomed favourable JPY dynamics and with only a small fraction of its constituents in negative territory. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.6%) echoed the performance in regional peers after the Mainland initially side-lined below-forecast Chinese inflation figures for a bulk of the session, with the US-China Phase One deal signing drawing closer.

FTSE 100

Ex Divs: Aveva (AVV LN) will trade without their most recent dividend, taking 0.04 points off of the FTSE 100. (Newswires)
